contentrichtext.text: French musician '''Valentin Clastrier''' (born 1947) is one of the few performers in the world specializing in contemporary music for the [[hurdy-gurdy]]; before Clastrier, the instrument was used primarily in the performance of European [[Medieval music|Medieval]] and folk musics. He began his career as a guitarist, and was introduced to the hurdy-gurdy in 1970. His instrument has 27 strings rather than the conventional six. Since 2006 Clastrier works together with Wolfgang Weichselbaumer [http://www.weichselbaumer.cc/] on a new prototype. Clastrier's strikingly original compositions for the instrument (in both acoustic and electroacoustic versions) have been recorded, in collaboration with other creative European musicians (including tubist and [[Serpent (instrument)|serpent]] player [[Michel Godard]], [[accordion]]ist [[Jean-Louis Matinier]], saxophonist/clarinetists [[Michaël Riessler]] and [[Louis Sclavis]], and percussionists [[Gérard Siracusa]] and [[Carlo Rizzo]]). ==See also== *[[Dominique Regef]] http://www.valentinclastrier.com/ [http://www.valentinclastrier.com/] {{Authority control|VIAF=79166341}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME =Clastrier, Valentin | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = 1947 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Clastrier, Valentin}} [[Category:1947 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:French musicians]] [[Category:Hurdy-gurdy players]]
